docs.lead_paragraph: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, suspected of fueling a spike in microcephaly, is at the core of one of the most alarming Brazilian health crises in decades.

headline.main: Alarm Spreads in Brazil Over a Virus and a Surge in Malformed Infants
headline.print_headline: Mosquito-Borne Peril to Babies Unsettles Brazil

docs.abstract: Brazilian researchers report mosquito-borne virus known as Zika is responsible for rapid surge in babies born with microcephaly, rare incurable condition in which their heads are abnormally small; nation has marked 2,782 cases in 2015, compared with 147 in 2014; many pregnant women in country are in state of panic; some scientists say more research is necessary before link with Zika can be established.
docs.snippet: The mosquito-borne Zika virus, suspected of fueling a spike in microcephaly, is at the core of one of the most alarming Brazilian health crises in decades.

byline.contributor: Paula Moura contributed reporting from São Paulo, Vinod Sreeharsha from Rio de Janeiro, and Donald G. McNeil Jr. from New York

docs.lead_paragraph: Neuroscientists have struggled to understand exactly how the mind’s cycles affect us. Studies of donated brains provide some answers.

headline.main: Seeking the Gears of Our Inner Clock
headline.print_headline: Seeking Gears of Our Inner Clock

docs.abstract: Dr Huda Akil study in The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences examines brains preserved at the University of California, Irvine, and concludes brain's production of RNA follows predictable pattern that affects body's circadian rhythms; pattern can be disrupted by depression and mood disorders.
docs.snippet: Neuroscientists have struggled to understand exactly how the mind’s cycles affect us. Studies of donated brains provide some answers.

keywords.value: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
